description: From Middle English descencioun, from Old French descension, from Latin dēscēnsiō, dēscēnsiōnem.

entries.meaning: (now rare) Descent; the act of descending. [from 15th c.]
examples: Death is followed by either ascension into a higher plane or descension into a lower plane.

entries.meaning: (astronomy, obsolete) The descent below the horizon of a celestial body. [16th–19th c.]
examples: For in regard of time (as we elsewhere declare) the stars do vary their longitudes, and consequently the times of their ascension and descension.
